Regulation .03A amended effective July 2, 2018 (45:13 Md. R. 667)
Regulation .04A, H amended effective July 2, 2018 (45:13 Md. R. 667)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Board” means the Maryland State Board of Nursing.

“Certificate holder” means an individual who has been issued a certificate by the Board to practice as a certified nursing assistant, a certified dialysis technician, or a certified medication technician.
“Conditions” means any requirements in a public or nonpublic order that a licensee or certificate holder is required to satisfy, which include, but are not limited to:
Treatment and counseling for a psychological or physical illness, including, but not limited to substance abuse;
Submission to drug and alcohol testing;
Abstinence from specified drugs;
Abstinence from alcohol;
Remedial training;
Inspection of a private practice site;
Monitoring;
Evaluation;
Supervision;
Compliance with a rehabilitation agreement;
Testing of clinical skills;
Submission of written reports;
A demonstration of knowledge or competency;
Submit to a physical or mental health examination;
Limitation of practice; and
Limitation on the administration of prescription or specified drugs to clients.
“Conduct” means behavior or action or a failure to behave or act, which results in a violation of the Maryland Nurse Practice Act or regulations adopted by the Board.
“Licensee” means an individual who:
Has been issued a license or certification by the Board to practice as:
A registered nurse;
A licensed practical nurse;
An advanced practice registered nurse;
An electrologist;
A licensed direct-entry midwife; or
A licensed certified midwife; or
Has a multistate licensure privilege to practice licensed practical nursing or registered nursing under the Nurse Licensure Compact.
“Multistate licensure privilege” has the meaning set forth in COMAR 10.27.01.01B.
“Recklessly” means characterized by the creation of a substantial and unjustifiable risk of harm to others and by a conscious, sometimes deliberate, disregard for or indifference to that risk.
“Sanction” means a disciplinary action against a licensee or certificate holder, including a reprimand, probation, suspension, revocation, or a monetary penalty.

section.heading: Sanctioning Guidelines.
section.text: Subject to the provisions of this chapter, the Board may impose sanctions for violations of the Maryland Nurse Practice Act and its regulations according to the guidelines set forth in the following categories:

para.text: Abuse — Physical and Psychological.

tr.td: (1) Unacceptable behavior directed to an individual, resulting in minimal harm or a risk of harm
(2) Abuse resulting in significant physical or psychological injury

para.text: Criminal History.

tr.td: (1) Convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude
(2) Convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a sexual offense

para.text: Disciplined by Another Licensing, Military, or Disciplinary Authority.

tr.td: Licensee or Certificate Holder is disciplined by a licensing, military, or disciplinary authority in this State or in any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court in this State or in any other state or country for an act that would be grounds for disciplinary action under the Maryland Board of Nursing’s disciplinary statutes

para.text: Diversion of Controlled Substances or Prescription Drugs or Manufacture, Sale, or Distribution of any Substance for an Illegal or Illegitimate Purpose.

tr.td: (1) Diversion without harm to self or others.
(2) Diversion creating risk of harm to self or others.
(3) Diversion with harm to self or others.
(4) Manufacture, sale or distribution of any substance for an illegal or illegitimate purpose.
(5) Diversion for purposes of selling to others

para.text: Noncompliance with Board Orders.

tr.td: (1) Failure to comply with a Board order
(2) Failure to comply with a Board order with additional unprofessional conduct
(3) Failure to comply with a Board order with serious physical injury or death of an individual, or the risk of significant physical injury or death

para.text: Practice Inconsistent with Generally Accepted Standards of Care.

tr.td: (1) Practice inconsistent with generally accepted standards resulting in no risk of harm or practice resulting in a risk of harm
(2) Practice inconsistent with generally accepted standards resulting in serious physical injury or death of a client, or a risk of significant physical injury or death
(3) Practice inconsistent with generally accepted standards that constitutes gross negligence

para.text: Sexual Misconduct.

tr.td: (1) Unsolicited conduct of a sexual nature, including physical contact that serves no diagnostic or treatment purpose
(2) A personal relationship that violates professional ethics
(3) Physical contact of a sexual nature that does not include force, intimidation, the use of drugs, or alcohol, and serves no diagnostic or treatment purpose
(4) Sexual conduct involving, but not limited to force, intimidation, the use of drugs, or alcohol, or multiple victims

para.text: Substance Abuse.

tr.td: (1) Misuse of drugs, alcohol, or any other substance for an illegal or illegitimate purpose without harm to others
(2) Misuse of drugs, alcohol, or any other substance for an illegal or illegitimate purpose resulting in client harm or risk of client harm

para.text: Unauthorized Practice.

tr.td: (1) Knowingly allowing an unauthorized individual to practice outside their scope of practice resulting in no client harm, minimal client harm, or greater than minimal client harm
(2) Knowingly allowing an unauthorized individual who practices outside their scope of practice resulting in no client harm or minimal client harm
(3) Knowingly allowing an unauthorized individual who practices outside their scope of practice resulting in greater than minimal client harm
(4) An unauthorized practice resulting from any violation not provided for in (1)—(3) above

para.text: Unprofessional Conduct.

tr.td: (1) Unprofessional Conduct resulting in no physical or psychological harm
(2) Failure to report a violation of the Nurse Practice Act
(3) Unprofessional conduct resulting in financial injury
(4) Unprofessional conduct resulting in physical or psychological harm or a risk of physical or psychological harm
(5) Failure to cooperate with a lawful investigation conducted by the Board
(6) Threatens, forces, intimidates, or influences a person to change or withhold evidence from the Board
(7) Unprofessional Conduct resulting from any violation not provided for in (1)—(6) above

para.text: Physical or Mental Incompetence.
Fraud, Deceit, or Misrepresentation.

tr.td: (1) Fraudulent or deceitful conduct or misrepresentation with minimal or no risk of physical, emotional, or financial harm
(2) Fraudulent or deceitful conduct or misrepresentation with physical, emotional, or financial harm or a risk of physical, emotional, or financial harm

(3) Fraudulent or deceitful conduct or misrepresentation with significant physical, emotional, or financial harm to client or others or serious risk of significant physical, emotional, or individual financial harm

para.text: Expulsion from Safe Practice Program.

tr.td: Is expelled from the Safe Practice Program established under Health Occupations Article, §8-208, Annotated Code of Maryland, for failure to comply with the conditions of the program

annotations.annotation: Health Occupations Article, §§1-606, 8-205(a)(1), 8-316, 8-6A-10, and 8-6B-18, Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: April 16, 2012 (39:7 Md. R. 492)
Regulation .02B amended effective September 10, 2018 (45:18 Md. R. 834); February 22, 2026 (52:17 Md. R. 875)
Regulation .07M amended effective September 10, 2018 (45:18 Md. R. 834)

section.heading: Exceptions.
section.text: This chapter does not apply to an individual who:

para.text: Assists at a birth in an emergency;

Is licensed as a health care practitioner in accordance with the Health Occupations Article, Annotated Code of Maryland whose scope of practice allows the individual to practice certified midwifery; or

Is a student practicing certified midwifery while engaged in an approved clinical midwifery education experience under the supervision of an individual licensed by the Board as a licensed certified midwife or a licensed nurse certified as a nurse midwife.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Accreditation Commission for Midwifery (ACME)” means the accrediting agency for midwifery education programs and institutions, or a successor organization, which is approved by the United States Department of Education.

“American College of Nurse Midwives (ACNM)” means the national professional association, or a successor organization, that represents advanced practice midwives, including certified nurse-midwives and certified midwives in the United States

“American Midwifery Certification Board (AMCB)” means the national certifying body for candidates in nurse-midwifery and midwifery, or a successor organization, which is approved by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies.
“Board” means the Maryland Board of Nursing.
“Central Repository” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §8-303(a), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Clinical practice guidelines” means written standards using guidelines established by:
The ACNM in Standards for the Practice of Midwifery, as amended or supplemented; or
Any other national certifying body recognized by the Board.
“Licensed certified midwife (LCM)” means an individual who has been issued a license by the Board to practice certified midwifery.
“Newborn” means an infant in the first 28 days after birth.
“Practice certified midwifery” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §8-6D-01(h), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Physician” means an individual licensed to practice medicine in the State.

section.heading: Qualifications for Applicants for Initial Licensure.
section.text: An applicant for initial licensure as a certified midwife shall:

para.text: Be of good moral character;
Submit to a criminal history records check in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §8-303, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Hold a current, valid national certification as a certified midwife from the AMCB;
Have graduated from a graduate-level midwifery education program accredited by the ACME; and
Have passed the AMCB certification examination.

section.heading: Requirements for Application for Initial Licensure.

para.text: An applicant for initial licensure as a certified midwife shall submit to the Board:
A completed application on the form that the Board requires;
Written, verified evidence that the applicant has met the requirements of Regulation .03C—E of this chapter;
Written, verified evidence that the applicant has submitted to a criminal history records check as required by Regulation .03B of this chapter by submitting:
Two sets of fingerprints, as required by the Central Repository and the Federal Bureau of Investigation; and
All fees required by the Central Repository and the FBI;

Any documentation requested from the applicant by the Board including, but not limited to, official certified or true test court documents and a signed, dated explanation written by the applicant, regarding the facts and circumstances, outcome, and current status of any criminal history record information received by the Board:
In accordance with Health Occupations Article, §8-303, Annotated Code of Maryland;
In an answer to a question on the Board’s application form; or
From any other source;
Any additional documentation requested by the Board if the documentation received from the applicant under §A(4) of this regulation is incomplete or insufficient; and
A fee for initial licensure as specified under Regulation .13 of this chapter.
If an application is not complete when initially submitted to the Board by the applicant, the applicant shall have no longer than 12 months from the date the application is received by the Board to:
Complete the application; and
Provide all information and documents required in §A of this regulation.

If an applicant fails to provide to the Board a complete application and any additional documentation requested by the Board in §A of this regulation within 12 months from the date the application is received by the Board, then the application:
Shall be considered abandoned; and
May be destroyed.
Once an application is deemed abandoned under §C of this regulation, an individual seeking licensure shall:
Submit a new application;
Meet all of the requirements for licensure; and
Pay the required fees in accordance with Regulation .13 of this chapter in effect at the time of re-application.

An individual who has graduated from a graduate level accredited program for midwifery education program approved by the ACME and who has taken the AMCB national certification examination but is waiting for results may practice as a certified midwife graduate before certification if the:

Practice is under the supervision of a licensed certified midwife or certified nurse midwife who shall be physically present at the location of service and available to the certified midwife graduate;
Supervising midwife and certified midwife graduate execute a written supervision agreement on the form required by the Board; and
Certified midwife graduate files with the Board a copy of the:
Admission slip to the Board-approved certification examination; and
Signed supervision agreement.

A certified midwife graduate who has entered into a supervision agreement under this regulation shall immediately notify the Board and the supervising midwife of the results of the AMCB certification examination.

A certified midwife graduate may not continue to practice under a supervision agreement under this regulation for more than 1 year from the filing of all documents required under §A(3) of this regulation, or after the denial of AMCB certification, whichever occurs first.
A license issued under this regulation authorizes the licensee to practice licensed certified midwifery while the license is active.
Unless renewed, a license expires on October 28 of every even-numbered year, except that an initial license shall not expire within 180 days of the date of issuance.
Before a license expires, the licensed certified midwife may renew the license for an additional 2-year term if the licensed certified midwife:
Is otherwise entitled to be licensed;
Pays to the Board the renewal fee specified in Regulation .13 of this chapter; and
Submits to the Board:
A renewal application on the form that the Board requires;
Satisfactory evidence of current national certification as a certified midwife by AMCB; and
If required to submit to a criminal history records check in accordance with § C of this regulation, evidence of submission to a criminal history records check as required by the Board.
A licensed certified midwife shall submit to a criminal history records check in order to renew a license in accordance with the following schedule:
In 2025—all applicants with an August or September birth month;
In 2026—all applicants with a September or October birth month;
In 2027—all applicants with an October or November birth month;
In 2028— all applicants with a November or December birth month;
In 2029—all applicants with a December or January birth month;
In 2030—all applicants with a January or February birth month;
In 2031—all applicants with a February or March birth month;
In 2032—all applicants with a March or April birth month;
In 2033—all applicants with an April or May birth month;
In 2034—all applicants with a May or June birth month; and
In 2035—all applicants with a June or July birth month.
In 2036—all applicants with a July or August birth month;
The Board may grant a 30-day extension beyond a license’s expiration date so that the license may be renewed before it expires.

section.heading: Change in Name or Address.
section.text: A licensed certified midwife shall provide written notice to the Board, on the form required by the Board, within 60 days of a change of:

para.text: Name, along with legal documentation of the change; or
Address.
A licensed certified midwife who provides clinical midwifery services across the reproductive lifespan in accordance with this subtitle shall:
Maintain a health record for each client;
In the case of a transfer of care to another provider or a facility, transfer the client’s health records with the client; and
Comply with applicable State laws and regulations governing the creation and maintenance of health care records.

A licensed certified midwife who provides clinical midwifery services shall have available at all times for examination by the Board, written clinical practice guidelines that cover all aspects of care, practice, and quality assurance, including but not limited to:
A plan for emergency consultation;
A plan for transfer of care; and
A plan for admission of the client or newborn to a hospital within the client’s geographic area.
A licensed certified midwife may perform the following functions:
Independent management of clients appropriate to the skill and educational preparation of the licensed certified midwife and the licensed certified midwife's clinical practice guidelines;
Consultation or collaboration with a physician or other health care provider as needed; and
Referral of clients with complications beyond the scope of practice of the licensed certified midwife to another licensed health care practitioner, including a licensed physician.
A licensed certified midwife shall keep a record of all cases attended.

A licensed certified midwife has the right and obligation to refuse to perform any delegated medical act, oral or written, if, in the licensed certified midwife’s judgment, it is unsafe or an invalidly prescribed medical act or beyond the competence of the licensed certified midwife, in which case the licensed certified midwife shall immediately notify the delegating physician.
Subject to the hearing provisions of COMAR 10.01.03, the Department may suspend or revoke a certificate if the individual:
Fraudulently or deceptively obtains or attempts to obtain a certificate for a community health worker or for another individual;
Fraudulently or deceptively uses a certificate;
Otherwise fails to meet substantially the standards for certification adopted under this chapter;

Is convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or to a crime involving moral turpitude, whether or not any appeal or other proceeding is pending to have the conviction or plea set aside;
Performs the duties of a community health worker while:
Under the influence of alcohol; or

Using any narcotic or controlled dangerous substance, as defined in Criminal Law Article, §5–101, Annotated Code of Maryland, or other drug that is in excess of therapeutic amounts or without valid medical indication;

Is disciplined by a licensing or disciplinary authority of any other state or country or convicted or disciplined by a court of any state, territory, or country for an act that would be grounds for suspension or revocation action under this title;
Performs the duties of a certified community health worker with an unauthorized person or supervises or aids an unauthorized person in performing the duties of a certified community health worker;
Willfully makes or files a false report or record while performing the duties of a certified community health worker;
Willfully fails to file or record any report as required under law, willfully impedes or obstructs the filing or recording of the report, or induces another to fail to file or record the report;
Commits an act of unprofessional conduct in performing the duties of a community health worker;

Refuses, withholds from, denies, or discriminates against an individual with regard to the provision of professional services for which the individual is certified and qualified to render because of the individual’s race, sex, creed, color, national origin, marital status, sexual orientation, age, gender identity, or disability; or
Fails to maintain on file with the Department a current resident address or employment address or notify the Department when the residency or place of employment changes.
The Department shall proceed with the suspension or revocation in accordance with the provisions in COMAR 10.01.03.
The Department shall send written notice of intent to suspend or revoke a certificate to the individual and identify the specific deficiencies.
Within 30 calendar days after receipt of written notice, the individual may submit to the Department:
A written plan by the individual to meet the applicable deficiencies; or
A written response setting forth documentation that the individual is meeting and maintaining each of the applicable requirements as set forth in this chapter.
Based on deficiencies and the individual’s response, if any, the Department may suspend, revoke, or reinstate a certificate.
Appealing the Decision to Suspend or Revoke a Certificate.

An individual may appeal the decision to suspend or revoke a certificate by submitting a request in writing to the Department within 30 calendar days of the date on the notice of suspension or revocation of a certificate.
If an individual submits an appeal, the Department, within 60 calendar days, shall:
Grant or deny the appeal; and
Send individual written notice:
Indicating whether the appeal has been granted or denied; and
Providing an explanation of the decision.
The Department may not refund a fee if a certification is suspended or revoked.
An individual may request a hearing within 10 calendar days after receipt of written notice.
When the Department receives the request, it will follow hearing procedures in accordance with COMAR 10.01.03.

section.heading: Compliance.
section.text: The certified midwife shall develop and comply with clinical practice guidelines as defined in Regulation .01B of this chapter.

section.heading: Prescribing and Dispensing of Substances by a Licensed Certified Midwife.

para.text: Pursuant to Health Occupations Article, §8-6D-01, Annotated Code of Maryland, a licensed certified midwife may:
Prescribe substances commonly used in the practice of midwifery; and
Prescribe controlled dangerous substances on Schedules II-V under Criminal Law Article, §§5-403—5-406, Annotated Code of Maryland, commonly used in the practice of midwifery; and
Dispense substances prescribed in accordance with §A(1)—(2)of this regulation in the course of treating a client at a:
Nonprofit medical facility or clinic;
Health center operating on the campus of an institution of higher education;
Public health facility;
Medical facility under contract with a State or local health department; or
Facility funded with public funds.
A licensed certified midwife who personally prepares and dispenses a drug in the course of treating a client as authorized under §A(3) of this regulation shall:
Comply with the labeling requirements of Health Occupations Article, §12-505, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Record the dispensing of the prescription drug on the client's chart;

Allow the Office of Controlled Substances Administration to enter and inspect the licensed certified midwife's office at all reasonable hours in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §8-508, Annotated Code of Maryland ; and
Except for starter dosages or samples dispensed without charge:
Provide the client with a written prescription;
Maintain prescription files; and
Maintain a separate file for Schedule II prescriptions for a period of at least 7 years.
A licensed certified midwife may personally prepare and dispense a starter dosage of any drug the licensed certified midwife is authorized to prescribe to a client if:
The starter dosage complies with the labeling requirements of Health Occupations Article, §12-505, Annotated Code of Maryland;
No charge is made for the starter dosage; and
The licensed certified midwife enters an appropriate record in the client’s medical record.

section.heading: Unlawful Practices.
section.text: Pursuant to Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Subtitle 6D, Annotated Code of Maryland, an individual may not:

para.text: Practice licensed certified midwifery unless licensed under this subtitle or otherwise permitted by law to engage in those activities;
Use the title “certified midwife” or the abbreviation “CM” unless licensed by the Board with the intent to represent that the individual practices licensed certified midwifery in the State;

Represent to the public by title, description of service, method, procedure, or otherwise that the individual is authorized to practice licensed certified midwifery in this State unless licensed under this subtitle; or
Advertise in a manner that is unreasonable, misleading, or fraudulent.
The fees listed in this regulation are nonrefundable.
The fees are as follows:
Initial application fee—$150;
Biennial renewal fee—$120;
Biennial reinstatement fee—$70;
Verification of licensure fee—$45; and
Returned check fee—$30.
Health Care Practitioner User Fee.

In addition to a license fee, each licensed certified midwife shall pay a non-refundable health care practitioner user fee assessed by the Maryland Health Care Commission in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-111(b)(4), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The health care practitioner user fee shall be:
In addition to the licensing fee paid to the Board; and
Collected with the application for an initial or renewal license.
The amount of the assessed health care practitioner user fee shall be double the amount of the annual health care practitioner user fee for biennial licensure.
The Board shall:
Account for the health care practitioner user fees; and
(b) Transfer the health care practitioner user fees to the Maryland Health Care Commission on a quarterly basis.

annotations.annotation: Health Occupations Article, §§ 8-101, 8-205, 8-208, 8-508, 8-601, 8-6A-02, 8-6D-01 through 8-6D-15, 8-701, 8-708, and 8-710, Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: February 22, 2026 (52:17 Md. R. 875)

container.heading: Delegation of Technical Acts by a Licensed Certified Midwife

para.text: This chapter governs the delegation of other technical tasks by a licensed certified midwife to an assistant not otherwise authorized under Health Occupations Article, Annotated Code of Maryland.
This chapter may not be construed:
As establishing the licensure, certification, or registration of assistants by the Board;

To apply to an individual who is licensed, certified, or registered by a health occupations regulatory board, or health occupation students, acting pursuant to Health Occupations Article, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
To mean that this chapter overrides, or is to be used in lieu of, more stringent regulations, policies, and procedures established by State licensure or certification requirements.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Assistant” means an individual:
To whom only routine technical tasks are delegated by a licensed certified midwife;
Who is trained; and
Who is not licensed, certified, registered, or otherwise authorized by law by the Board, or any other State health occupations board, to practice any health occupation in the State.
“Asynchronous telehealth interaction” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §1-1001(b), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Board” means the Maryland Board of Nursing.
“Delegating Licensed Certified Midwife (LCM)” means a licensed certified midwife who directs an assistant to perform technical tasks.
“Direct supervision” means oversight exercised by a delegating licensed certified midwife who is:
Personally treating the client; and
In the physical presence of the client and the assistant.
“Licensed Certified Midwife (LCM)” means an individual who has been issued a license by the Board to practice certified midwifery in accordance with COMAR 10.69.01.
Mechanical Act.
“Mechanical act” means an act which does not require professional judgment, medical or pharmaceutical training, or discretion.
“Mechanical act” does not include:
Selecting a drug;
Labeling;
Measuring or calculating dosages;
Substituting one drug for another, including substituting a generic or brand drug for the prescribed drug;
Substituting one dosage form of a drug for another;
Altering the route of administration; or
Counseling client.
“On-site supervision” means oversight exercised by a delegating licensed certified midwife who is:
Present at the same site as the assistant and the client; and
Able to be immediately available in person during the assistant’s performance of a delegated act; or

In the context of a synchronous telehealth interaction, able to be immediately available via secure telecommunications technology to the telehealth visit during the assistant’s performance of a delegated act; or
In the context of an asynchronous telehealth interaction, is able to review the assistant’s work and interact with the assistant before communication with the client.
“Site” means any facility or location, including those defined in Health-General Article, §§19-114 and 19-3B-01(b), Annotated Code of Maryland, used for the delivery of health services.
“Synchronous telehealth interaction” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §1-1001(d), Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Technical task” means a routine clinical act or task that does not require clinical or midwifery judgment and is performed with supervision as specified within this chapter.
“Trained” means possessing the knowledge, skills, and abilities, as determined by the delegating licensed certified midwife, to perform delegated technical tasks.
A licensed certified midwife who delegates shall:
Assess the risk to the client and the outcome of the delegated acts;
Delegate only those technical tasks that are customary to the practice of a licensed certified midwife;
Delegate only those technical tasks for which the assistant has been trained;
Be responsible for the acts of the assistant;
Supervise the assistant in accordance with this chapter; and
If dispensing prescription medication under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland, perform a final check of the prescription medication before it is provided to the client.

The responsibility for the delegated act cannot be transferred from the delegating licensed certified midwife to another licensed certified midwife, or to another licensed health care provider that is authorized to delegate clinical and technical tasks, without:
The expressed consent of the other licensed certified midwife or licensed health care provider; and
Informing the assistant.

section.heading: Scope of Delegation to an Assistant.

para.text: A licensed certified midwife may not delegate technical tasks to an assistant which shall, by law or regulation, be performed only by an individual that is required to be licensed, certified, registered, or otherwise recognized pursuant to any State laws.
A licensed certified midwife may delegate technical tasks, consistent with the approved policies and procedures of the site, in the following categories:
Surgical technical tasks that the delegating licensed certified midwife directly orders while present and personally performing the surgery in the same surgical field; and
Nonsurgical technical tasks while the assistant is under the delegating licensed certified midwife’s direct supervision or on-site supervision.

Except as provided in §§B(1) and D of this regulation, a licensed certified midwife shall provide a minimum of on-site supervision when delegating technical tasks to an assistant, including, but not limited to, the following:
Client preparation for physical examination;
Client history interview;

Collecting and processing specimens, such as performing phlebotomy, inoculating culture media, pregnancy tests; dipstick and microscopic urinalysis, and microbiology including rapid streptococcal testing and throat cultures;
Preparing and performing laboratory tests under State and Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments regulations;
Clinical tests;
Transmitting prescriptions to a pharmacy;
Preparing and administering oral drugs;
Establishing a peripheral intravenous line; and
Preparing and administering injections including small amounts of local anesthetics if provided either:
Intradermal;
Subcutaneous; or
Intramuscular in the deltoid, gluteal, or vastus lateralis.
When delegating injecting intravenous drugs or contrast materials to an assistant, a licensed certified midwife shall provide direct supervision.

A licensed certified midwife who is dispensing prescription medication under Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland may delegate only mechanical acts involved in dispensing a drug.
A licensed certified midwife may not delegate to an assistant any act that requires the exercise of clinical judgment by a licensed certified midwife, including, but not limited to:
Conducting physical examinations;
Administering any form of anesthetic agent or agent of conscious sedation other than topical anesthetics or small amounts of local anesthetics;
Initiating independently any form of treatment, except for cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or other forms of emergency treatment authorized to be performed by non-clinicians under State law;
Establishing a diagnosis or giving clinical advice; and
Providing physical therapy.
An assistant acting beyond the scope of this chapter may be:
Considered to be engaged in the unlicensed practice of licensed certified midwifery or any other health occupation regulated by the State; and

Subject to all applicable fines and penalties in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §§8-701 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland and applicable regulations, or any other applicable provision of Health Occupations Article, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A delegating licensed certified midwife, through either act or omission, facilitation, or otherwise enabling or forcing an assistant to practice beyond the scope of this chapter, may be subject to discipline as set forth in Health Occupations Article, §8-6D-10, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A delegating licensed certified midwife may not:
Require an assistant to perform a delegated technical task; or
Permit an assistant to delegate any act to another individual.

section.heading: Enforcement.
section.text: The Board shall conduct any necessary investigation regarding the failure to comply with the requirements of Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter, and it may refer any complaint or investigation to any other appropriate licensing or regulatory authority in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

annotations.annotation: Health Occupations Article, §§ 8-101, 8-205, 8-208, 8-508, 8-601, 8-6A-02, 8-6D-01 through 8-6D-15, 8-701, 8-708, and 8-710, Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: February 22, 2026 (52:17 Md. R. 875)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
Abandonment.

“Abandonment” means failure to provide or make reasonable arrangements for the continuation of care for a client in need of immediate care or failure to provide reasonable notice to a facility or practice under circumstances that seriously impair the delivery of clinical care to clients.
“Abandonment” does not include the declining by a licensed certified midwife of employer-stipulated mandatory overtime.
“Board” means the Board of Nursing.
“Client” means a patient, resident, or recipient of care.
“Electronic devices” means, but is not limited to, any of the following:
Telephones with recording and picture-taking ability;
Digital cameras or any other device that can record pictures and data;
Facsimile machines, photocopiers, and scanners for copying; and
Recording devices.
“Licensed certified midwife (LCM)” means an individual who has been issued a license by the Board to practice certified midwifery in accordance with COMAR 10.69.01.
Social Media.
“Social media” means any form of electronic communication.

“Social media” includes but is not limited to communication by use of websites or other electronic applications for social networking, commentary, and blogging through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content such as videos.
A licensed certified midwife shall:

Provide services with respect for human dignity and the uniqueness of a client unrestricted by consideration of social or economic status, religious affiliation, personal attributes, race, sexual orientation, gender identity, or the nature of health problems;
Safeguard a client's right to privacy by maintaining confidentiality of information;
Act to safeguard a client and the public if health care and safety are affected by the incompetent, unethical, or illegal practice of any person;
Promptly report a breach of confidentiality or privacy;
Assume responsibility and accountability for individual clinical judgments and actions;
Maintain competence in licensed certified midwifery;
Exercise informed judgment and use individual competence and qualifications as criteria in seeking consultation, accepting responsibilities, and when delegating; and
Inform the Board regarding unethical conduct by another licensed certified midwife.
A licensed certified midwife may not, when acting in the capacity or identity of a licensed certified midwife:
Knowingly participate in or condone dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation;
Engage or participate in an action that violates or diminishes the civil or legal rights of a client;
Perform new techniques and procedures without adequate education and practice;
Assume duties and responsibilities in the practice of licensed certified midwifery without adequate preparation or without maintaining competency;
Practice clinically if unfit to perform procedures or make decisions because of physical or mental impairment, including, but not limited to, the effects of prescription drugs;
If engaged in research, coerce or pressure a subject to participate or continue to participate in the research; or
Abandon a client.

A licensed certified midwife may not engage in behavior that dishonors the profession whether or not they are acting in the capacity or identity of a licensed certified midwife, including, but not limited to:
Verbal abuse, including use of racial or ethnic slurs, directed toward a coworker, employer, Board staff member, client, or client’s family member;
Physically abusing, threatening, or intimidating a coworker, employer, Board staff member, client, or client’s family member;
Deceiving, defrauding, or stealing from a coworker, employer, client, or client’s family member;
Diverting any medication or providing false or misleading information to an authorized prescriber or a pharmacist to obtain or attempt to obtain any medication;

Knowingly employ another person to practice, engage in, or attempt to practice, or engage in an occupation or profession licensed by the Board if the employee is not licensed to do so in accordance with Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Performing acts beyond the authorized scope of the level of midwifery practice for which the individual is licensed;
Obtaining or copying any part of a client’s health record for purposes other than:
Providing health care to the client;
Conducting quality improvement activities;
Complying with legal requirements such as a subpoena; or
Allowing a midwifery student to use records for educational purposes if client identification has been redacted or disguised;
Using, possessing, supplying, administering, or attempting to use, possess, supply, or administer prescription drugs or controlled dangerous substances without valid clinical indication;

Reporting for employment under the influence of alcohol or a controlled dangerous substance or submitting a pre-employment sample that is positive for alcohol or a controlled dangerous substance without having provided evidence of valid prescriptions for all controlled dangerous substances in the sample;
Reporting for employment under the influence of an illicit drug or submitting a pre-employment sample that is positive for an illicit drug;
Using the power, influence, or knowledge, inherent in or obtained during the provider-client relationship, for the licensee’s personal gratification or benefit;
Engaging in unprofessional or immoral conduct;
Misrepresenting or concealing a material fact in obtaining a license, renewing a license, or reinstating a license; or

Committing an act of moral turpitude, dishonesty, or corruption when the act directly or indirectly affects the health, welfare, or safety of the citizens of this State, and, if the act constitutes a crime, conviction thereof in a criminal proceeding is not a condition precedent to disciplinary action.
A licensed certified midwife may not engage in sexual misconduct. Sexual misconduct includes, but is not limited to:
Sexual behavior with a client in the context of a professional evaluation, treatment, procedure, or service to the client, regardless of the setting in which the professional service is rendered;
Sexual behavior with a client under the pretext of diagnostic or therapeutic intent or benefit;
Solicitation of a sexual relationship, whether consensual or nonconsensual, with a client;
Sexual advances toward, or the request of sexual favors from, a coworker, student, employer, client, or client’s family member;
Discussion of nontherapeutic sexual matters while treating a client;
Taking photographs of a client for a sexual purpose;
Sexual harassment of a coworker, student, employer, client, or client’s family member;
Sexual contact with an incompetent or unconscious client;
Intentionally exposing any of the licensee's sexual body parts; and
Intentionally exposing any of the client’s sexual body parts for a nontherapeutic purpose.
Electronic devices may not be used to record medical records and take pictures or videos of clients without written client authorization.
A licensed certified midwife:
May not make use of electronic devices and social media to transmit or place any client information online; and
Shall adhere to the following principles for the use of electronic devices and social media:
Every licensed certified midwife has an obligation to understand the nature, benefits, and consequences of the use of electronic devices and participating in social media networking;
Licensed certified midwives are bound to observe ethically prescribed client-provider boundaries online as in any other setting;
Client information shall be maintained in separate encrypted and secured files on personal computers and online;
A licensed certified midwife has an obligation to report any electronically generated material that could harm a client’s privacy rights; and
The standards of professionalism are the same when using electronic devices and social media as in any other circumstance.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Violation of this chapter may result in the Board taking disciplinary action against a licensed certified midwife pursuant to Health Occupations Article, §8-6D-10, Annotated Code of Maryland.

annotations.annotation: Health Occupations Article, §§ 8-101, 8-205, 8-208, 8-508, 8-601, 8-6A-02, 8-6D-01 through 8-6D-15, 8-701, 8-708, and 8-710, Annotated Code of Maryland
Effective date: February 22, 2026 (52:17 Md. R. 875)

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Local police department” means:
The police department of any municipal corporation;
The police department of any county; and
The sheriff's department of any county that has highway traffic patrol responsibilities.
“Owner” means the registered owner of a motor vehicle or a lessee of a motor vehicle under a lease of 6 months or longer.
“Recorded image” means an image recorded by a work zone speed control system:
On:
A photograph;
A microphotograph;
An electronic image;
Videotape; or
Any other medium; and
Showing:
The rear of a motor vehicle;
At least two timed-stamped images of the motor vehicle that include the same stationary object near the motor vehicle; and
On at least one image or portion of tape, a clear and legible identification of the entire registration plate number of the motor vehicle.
“State police department” means the Department of State Police and the Maryland Transportation Authority Police.
“Work zone” means a segment of a highway:

That is identified as a temporary traffic control zone by traffic control devices that are placed or installed in general conformance with the State manual and specifications adopted for a uniform system of traffic control devices;

Where highway construction, repair, maintenance, utility work, or related activity, including the placement, installation, maintenance, or removal of a work zone traffic control device, is being performed regardless of whether workers are present; and
That is equipped with:
Signage designating each entrance and exit to the work zone; and
Flashing lights that operate whenever workers are present at the work zone.
“Work zone speed control system” means a device that:

Has one or more motor vehicle sensors connected to a camera system capable of producing recorded images of motor vehicles traveling at or above a predetermined speed in or approaching a work zone; and
Is equipped with flashing blue lights.
“Work zone speed control system operator” means an individual who has been trained and certified to operate a work zone speed control system and who is:
A police officer;
A representative of a local police department;
A representative of a State police department; or
A State Highway Administration contractor.

section.heading: Authorization, Site Qualification, and Operator Selection.

para.text: A local police department or State police department may not deploy any work zone speed control system without the permission of the State or local agency that maintains the highway on which the work zone is to be located.

The State or local agency that maintains the highway is responsible for ensuring that any segment of highway on which a work zone speed control system is deployed satisfies the requirements of Transportation Article, §21-810(b)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland.

The locations and times when work zone speed control systems are to be deployed within a work zone shall be jointly agreed upon by the agency that maintains the highway and the local police department or the State police department that deploys the work zone speed control system.

The deploying local police department or State police department shall determine whether the work zone speed control operator is a police officer, a representative of the police department, or a representative of a Maryland State Highway Administration contractor, for each location where a work zone speed control system is to be operated.
A work zone speed control system operator does not need to be present in person or remotely at the work zone when the speed control system is in use.

Multiple work zone speed control systems may be implemented and used in a work zone. If a work zone has more than one work zone speed control system in use, not more than one citation may be issued for the same registration plate for alleged violations that occur within a 1-hour period in the work zone.

An agency that maintains a highway on which a work zone speed control system is deployed and the local police department or State police department that deploys a work zone speed control system may use Internet sites and other media to notify the public regarding:
The general use of work zone speed control systems; or
The segments of highways where and the dates and times when, work zone speed control systems may be deployed.

A minimum of two signs approved by the State Highway Administration's Director of Traffic and Safety, alerting drivers to the possible operation of a work zone speed control system within the work zone shall be conspicuously placed in advance of each work zone speed control system. The positioning and spacing of these signs shall be as approved by the agency that maintains the highway on which the work zone is located.

A device clearly displaying the speeds of vehicles approaching the device shall be placed sufficiently in advance of each work zone speed control system to enable an alert driver traveling at a speed not more than 25 miles per hour in excess of the speed limit to safely reduce the vehicle's speed to the legal limit prior to the location where the vehicle's speed will be measured by the work zone speed control system. The positioning of the device displaying the speeds of approaching vehicles shall be as approved by the agency that maintains the highway on which the work zone is located.

A device that flashes when workers are present in the work zone shall be placed in advance of the first work zone speed control system in the work zone. The positioning of the device that flashes when workers are present shall be as approved by the agency that maintains the highway on which the work zone is located.

Each local police department and State police department that deploys a work zone speed control system shall require that each of its operators complete all manufacturer's training required by Transportation Article, §21-810(b)(4), Annotated Code of Maryland, governing the set up, testing, and operation of the work zone speed control system. Each local police department and State police department that deploys a work zone speed control system shall maintain a registry and files documenting the training and certification of each of its certified work zone speed control system operators.
Each local police department and State police department that acquires a work zone speed control system shall:
Obtain the initial and annual independent calibrations required by Transportation Article, §21-810(b)(6), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Maintain a file documenting the results of all calibration testing.

A work zone speed control system may not be used for enforcement purposes unless the agency deploying the system possesses the required initial and annual certificates from an independent laboratory that certifies that the system is properly calibrated.
A work zone speed control system operator shall complete the daily set-up log required by Transportation Article, §21-810(b)(5), Annotated Code of Maryland, that states:
The date and time when and the location where the system was set up; and
That the operator successfully performed, and the device passed, the manufacturer-specified self-tests before producing a recorded image.

The set-up log and these self-testing procedures under §D of this regulation shall be completed whenever the system is relocated and following each system start-up. A work zone speed control system may not be used for enforcement unless the operator has completed all required set-up logs, the system has passed all manufacturer-specified self-tests, and the system is operating properly.
A work zone speed control system may be used only to record the images of vehicles that are traveling at speeds at least 12 miles per hour above the posted speed limit in the work zone.

annotation.cite: Transportation Article, §21-810(m), Annotated Code of Maryland

tr.td: E. Inspection fee. Paid by an owner of a vehicle for which a salvage certificate has been issued who is applying for a certificate of title for the vehicle

section.heading: Driver's License and Identification Card Fees.

tr.td: A. Learner's Instructional Permit (Type 1Initial Noncommercial License). This fee includes issuance of an initial driver's license if the applicant meets all requirements before permit expiration, and includes the $5 fee for the conversion of provisional license to driver's license.

B. Learner's Instructional Permit (Type 2Subsequent Noncommercial License). This fee applies to learner's permits issued for purposes other than that of the initial license, and includes issuance of the license if the applicant meets all requirements before permit expiration.
(1) Instructional Permit. Includes issuance of license if issued before permit expiration.
(2) New Issuance. If a learner's instructional permit is not required.
F. Driver's license or privilege to drive—application for reinstatement:
(3) Issued to an incarcerated individual within 60 days of release from the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services or Federal Bureau of Prisons.
(4) New or corrected issued to youths approved by the Department of Juvenile Services.
(5) New or corrected issued to youths 15 to 20 years of age approved by the Department of Human Services for participation in certain programs.
(6) New or corrected issued to a homeless individual presenting documentation in accordance with COMAR 11.17.21.05A(5).
I. The fee for a driver's license or identification card issued for a period of time other than 5 years may be prorated on a 1-year basis.
(1) Special registration plates without emblem or logo. Fee paid on issuance of new or replacement plates.
(2) Special registration plates with emblem or logo. Fee paid on issuance of new or replacement plates.
(a) Fee paid on issuance of new plates.
(b) Annual fee in addition to the annual registration fee required.
(4) Special registration plates honoring State Agriculture.
(a) Fee paid on issuance of new plates.
(b) Annual fee in addition to the annual registration fee required.
(a) Fee paid on issuance of new plates.
(b) Annual fee in addition to the annual registration fee required.
B. Replacement of registration plates, validation tabs, and registration card.
C. Replacement of registration card of unaffixed validation tabs, or both.
D. Issuance of duplicate or additional registration card.
F. Penalty fee—registration flag or suspension removal.
G. Unused Registration Plates. This fee applies to the processing of a registration refund.
(1) New and used vehicle dealer (class 1A plates)
(4) Automotive dismantler, recycler, and scrap processor (class 2) plates
(3) Nonresident permit for vehicles not subject to registration
(4) Nonresident farm vehicle temporary registration plate:
(7) Nontitled in Maryland IRP registration fee
A. Vehicle emissions inspection fee. Every other year.
B. Vehicle emissions reinspection fee. After initial free inspection.
C. Vehicle emissions inspection advanced testing fee. Every other year.
D. Vehicle emissions inspection late fee. Per month or part of it.
E. Vehicle emissions inspection fleet test fee, per vehicle passed.
G. Driver improvement program rescheduling fee.
I. Alcohol education program rescheduling fee.
M. Copies of driver or vehicle records as follows:
(b) Depersonalized sales data – No Personally Identifiable Information
(c) Vehicle Emission Inspection Program test data– No Personally Identifiable Information
(2) Except as provided in subsection (1) of this section, sales of partial records
O. Restoration of repossessed documents or plates.

para.text: When used in this subtitle the following terms have the meanings given.
Terms Defined.

“Above-ground tank” means a tank that is situated in such a way that the entire surface area of the tank is completely above the plane of the adjacent surrounding surface and the entire surface area of the tank, including the tank bottom, is able to be visually inspected.
“Active life” of a facility means the period from the initial receipt of hazardous waste at the facility until the Secretary receives certification of final closure.

“Active portion” means that portion of a facility where treatment, storage, or disposal operations are being or have been conducted after the effective date of this subtitle and which is not a closed portion.
“Active range” means a military range that is currently in service and is being regularly used for range activities.
“Acute hazardous waste” means a hazardous waste that meets the listing criteria in COMAR 26.13.02.09A(2) and has therefore been assigned a hazard code of (H) in accordance with COMAR 26.13.02.15B;
“Aerosol can” means a non-refillable receptacle that:
Contains a gas compressed, liquified, or dissolved under pressure, the sole purpose of which is to expel a liquid, paste, or powder; and
Is fitted with a self-closing relief device that allows the contents to be ejected by the gas.

“Airbag inflator” means a small metal canister within an airbag module that generally houses explosive propellant and an initiator, and that causes an airbag module to deploy when an electronic pulse is received from a vehicle’s crash sensor.
“Airbag module” means a fully assembled unit that includes both an airbag inflator and the fabric cushion that is designed to inflate and deploy in the event of a vehicle crash.
“Airbag waste” means a hazardous waste airbag module or hazardous waste airbag inflator.
Airbag Waste Collection Facility.
“Airbag waste collection facility” means a facility that receives airbag waste from an airbag handler that is operating under the provisions of COMAR 26.13.02.04-7; and
“Airbag waste collection facility” does not include a facility that accumulates in-transit airbag waste for 10 days or less.
“Airbag waste handler” means a person, by site, that generates airbag waste that is subject to regulation under this subtitle.
“Ampule” means an airtight vial made of glass, plastic, metal, or any combination of these materials.

“Ancillary equipment” means a device including, but not limited to, such devices as piping, fittings, flanges, valves, and pumps, that is used to distribute, meter, or control the flow of hazardous waste from its point of generation to a storage or treatment tank or tanks, between hazardous waste storage and treatment tanks to a point of disposal on site, or to a point of shipment for disposal off site.
“Aquifer” means a geologic formation, group of formations, or part of a formation capable of yielding a significant amount of ground water to wells or springs.

“Authorized representative” means the person responsible for the overall operation of a facility or an operational unit (that is, part of a facility); for example, the plant manager, superintendent, or person of equivalent responsibility.
“Battery” means:
A device consisting of one or more electrically connected electrochemical cells which is designed to receive, store, and deliver electric energy; or
An intact, unbroken device which would otherwise meet the definition of battery in §B(4-1)(a) of this regulation from which the electrolyte has been removed.
“Boiler” means an enclosed device using controlled flame combustion and having one of the following characteristics:
The unit satisfies all of the following criteria:
The unit shall have physical provisions for recovering and exporting thermal energy in the form of steam, heated fluids, or heated gases.

The unit's combustion chamber and primary energy recovery section or sections shall be of integral design. To be of integral design, the combustion chamber and the primary energy recovery section or sections, such as waterwalls and superheaters, shall be physically formed into one manufactured or assembled unit. A unit in which the combustion chamber and the primary energy recovery section or sections are joined only by ducts or connections carrying flue gas is not integrally designed. However, secondary energy recovery equipment such as economizers or air preheaters need not be physically formed into the same unit as the combustion chamber and the primary energy recovery section. Process heaters which are units that transfer energy directly to a process stream and fluidized bed combustion units are not precluded from being boilers solely because they are not of integral design.
While in operation, the unit shall maintain a thermal energy recovery efficiency of at least 60 percent, calculated in terms of the recovered energy compared with the thermal value of the fuel.

The unit shall export and utilize at least 75 percent of the recovered energy, calculated on an annual basis. In this calculation, credit may not be given for recovered heat used internally in the same unit. Examples of internal use are the preheating of fuel or combustion air, and the driving of induced or forced draft fans or feedwater pumps.
The unit is one which the Secretary has determined, on a case-by-case basis, to be a boiler, after considering the standards in Regulation .04F of this chapter.
“Cathode ray tube (CRT)” means a vacuum tube, composed primarily of glass, that is the visual or video display component of an electronic device.
“Cathode ray tube (CRT) collector” means a person who receives used, intact CRTs for recycling, repair, resale or donation.

“Cathode ray tube (CRT) exporter” means any person in the United States who initiates a transaction to send used CRTs outside the United States and its territories for recycling or reuse, or any intermediary in the United States arranging for export of used CRTs to a location outside the United States and its territories for recycling or reuse.
“Cathode ray tube (CRT) glass manufacturer” means an operation or part of an operation that uses a furnace to manufacture CRT glass.
“Cathode ray tube (CRT) processing” means conducting together all of the following activities:
Receiving broken or intact CRTs;
Intentionally breaking intact CRTs or further breaking or separating broken CRTs; and
Sorting or otherwise managing glass removed from CRT monitors.
Chemical Agents and Munitions.
“Chemical agents and munitions” means an agent or munition that, through its chemical properties, produces lethal or other damaging effects on human beings.
“Chemical agents and munitions” does not include riot control agents, chemical herbicides, smoke, and other obscuration materials.

“Closed portion” means that portion of a facility which an owner or operator has closed in accordance with the approved facility closure plan and all applicable closure requirements. (See also “active portion” and “inactive portion”.)
“Component” means either the tank or ancillary equipment of a tank system.
“Confined aquifer” means an aquifer:
Bounded above and below by impermeable beds or by beds of distinctly lower permeability than that of the aquifer itself;
Containing confined ground water.
“Consignee” means the ultimate treatment, storage, or disposal facility in a receiving country to which a hazardous waste will be sent.

“Constituent” or “hazardous waste constituent” means a constituent which caused the Secretary to list the hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19 or a constituent listed in Table 1 of COMAR 26.13.02.14.
“Contained” means held in a unit, including a land-based unit, that meets the criteria of Regulation .04L(4) of this chapter;
“Container” means any portable device in which a material is stored, transported, treated, disposed of, or otherwise handled.
“Containment building” means a hazardous waste management unit that:
Is a completely enclosed, self-supporting structure;
Is designed and constructed of manmade materials; and
Provides for containment of hazardous constituents within the unit comparable to the degree of containment that would be provided by a:
Container managed in accordance with COMAR 26.13.05.09; or
Tank managed in accordance with COMAR 26.13.05.10.

“Contingency plan” means a document setting out an organized, planned, and coordinated course of action to be followed in case of a fire, explosion, or release of hazardous waste or hazardous waste constituents which could threaten human health or the environment.
“Controlled hazardous substance” means a hazardous waste as defined in COMAR 26.13.02, except as provided in COMAR 26.13.02.06.
“Corrosion expert” means an individual who is:

Qualified to engage in the practice of corrosion control on buried or submerged metal piping systems and metal tanks by reason of that individual's knowledge of the physical sciences and the principles of engineering and mathematics, acquired by a professional education and related practical experience; and

Certified as being qualified by the National Association of Corrosion Engineers (NACE), or who is a registered professional engineer who has certification or licensing that includes education and experience in corrosion control on buried or submerged metal piping systems and metal tanks.
Debris.
“Debris” means solid material exceeding a 60-millimeter particle size that is intended for disposal and that is:
A manufactured object;
Plant or animal material;
Natural geologic material; or

A mixture consisting of debris as defined in §B(10-3)(a)(i)—(iii) of this regulation that has not been treated to the standards established in 40 CFR §268.45, and other material if the mixture is comprised primarily of debris, by volume, based on visual inspection.
“Debris” does not mean any material for which a specific treatment standard is provided in 40 CFR Part 268 Subpart D, namely:
Lead acid batteries;
Cadmium batteries;
Radioactive lead solids;
Process residuals such as smelter slag and residues from the treatment of waste, wastewater, sludges, or air emission residues; and
Intact containers of hazardous waste that are not ruptured and that retain at least 75 percent of their original volume.
“Department” means the Department of the Environment.
“Designated facility” means:

A hazardous waste treatment, storage, disposal, or recycling facility which has been designated on the manifest by the generator under COMAR 26.13.03.04, a corresponding regulation of another state, or 40 CFR §262.20, and:
Has received a permit or interim status in accordance with the requirements of COMAR 26.13.07;
Has received a permit or interim status in accordance with the requirements of 40 CFR Parts 270 and 124;
Has received a permit or interim status from a state authorized in accordance with 40 CFR Part 271;

Is allowed by the state in which the facility is located to accept the waste, if the state has been authorized in accordance with 40 CFR Part 271 but the state has not yet obtained authorization from EPA to regulate that particular waste as hazardous; or
Is regulated under COMAR 26.13.02.06C(2), COMAR 26.13.10.04, 40 CFR §261.6(c)(2), 40 CFR Part 266, Subpart F, or analogous authorities in other states; or
A generator site designated on the manifest to receive its waste as a return shipment from a facility that has rejected the waste in accordance with COMAR 26.13.05.05C(6) or 26.13.06.05A.
Destination Facility.
“Destination facility” means a facility that treats, disposes of, or recycles a particular category of universal waste, except as provided in §B(12-1)(b) of this regulation.
“Destination facility” does not mean:

A facility for which the treatment, disposal, or recycling of a particular category of universal waste consists only of the management activities described in COMAR 26.13.10.12, .14, or .15B(3), including large quantity handlers of universal waste that are made subject to these requirements in COMAR 26.13.10.20A, C, and D; or
A facility at which a particular category of universal waste is only accumulated, with respect to that category of universal waste.
“Dike” means an embankment or ridge of either natural or man-made materials used to prevent the movement of liquids, sludges, solids, or other materials.
“Dioxins” means tetra, penta, hexa, hepta, and octa-chlorinated dibenzo dioxins.
“Discharge” or “hazardous waste discharge” means the accidental or intentional spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, or dumping of hazardous waste into or on any land or water.

“Disposal” means the discharge, deposit, injection, dumping, spilling, leaking, or placing of any solid waste or hazardous waste into or on any land or water so that the solid waste or hazardous waste or any constituent thereof may enter the environment or be emitted into the air or discharged into any waters, including ground waters.
“Disposal facility” means a facility or part of a facility at which hazardous waste is intentionally placed into or on any land or water, and at which waste will remain after closure.

“Drip pad” means an engineered structure consisting of a curbed, free-draining base which is constructed of non-earthen materials and designed to convey preservative kick-back or drippage from treated wood, precipitation, and surface water run-on to an associated collection system at wood-preserving plants.
“Drug Enforcement Administration” means the United States Drug Enforcement Administration;

“Electrochemical cell” means a system consisting of an anode, a cathode, an electrolyte, and any electrical or mechanical connections that may be needed to allow the system to deliver or receive electrical energy.

“Electronic manifest (e-manifest)” means the electronic format of the hazardous waste manifest that is obtained from EPA’s national electronic manifest system and transmitted electronically to the system, and that is the legal equivalent of EPA Forms 8700-22 (manifest) and 8700-22A (continuation sheet).

“Electronic manifest system (e-manifest system)” means EPA’s national information technology system through which the electronic manifest may be obtained, completed, transmitted, and distributed to users of the electronic manifest and to regulatory agencies.
“Elementary neutralization unit” means a device which:

Is used for neutralizing wastes which are hazardous waste only because they exhibit the corrosivity characteristic defined in COMAR 26.13.02.12, or are listed in COMAR 26.13.02.16—.19 only for this reason; and
Is a tank, tank system, container, transport vehicle, or vessel.
“EPA” means the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

“EPA Acknowledgement of Consent” means the cable sent to EPA from the U.S. Embassy in a receiving country that acknowledges the written consent of the receiving country to accept a hazardous waste and describes the terms and conditions of the receiving country's consent to the shipment.
“EPA hazardous waste number” means the number assigned by EPA to each hazardous waste listed in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19, and to each characteristic identified in COMAR 26.13.02.10—.14.
“EPA identification number” means the number assigned by EPA or by a state acting on EPA's behalf to each generator, transporter, and treatment, storage, or disposal facility.
“Equivalent method” means any testing or analytical method approved by the Secretary under Regulation .04A and B of this chapter.
“Evaluated hazardous waste pharmaceutical” means a prescription hazardous waste pharmaceutical that:
Has been evaluated by a reverse distributor in accordance with COMAR 26.13.10.49 and 40 CFR §266.510(a)(3); and
Will not be sent to another reverse distributor for further evaluation or verification of manufacturer credit.

“Existing hazardous waste management facility” or “existing facility” means a facility which was in operation, or for which construction had commenced, on or before November 18, 1980. Construction had commenced if:
The owner or operator has obtained all necessary federal, State, and local preconstruction approvals or permits;

A continuous physical, on-site construction program has begun, or the owner or operator has entered into contractual obligations, which cannot be cancelled or modified without substantial loss, for construction of the facility to be completed within a reasonable time.
“Existing portion” means that land surface area of an existing hazardous waste management facility on which wastes have been placed before July 26, 1982.
“Existing tank system” or “existing component” means a tank system or component that is used for the storage or treatment of hazardous waste and that satisfies the following criteria:
It is in operation; or

It is an underground tank which cannot be entered for inspection for which installation has begun on or before July 14, 1986, or it is any other tank for which installation has begun by July 1, 1993, with the beginning of installation being determined by the criteria of COMAR 26.13.05.10A(4).
“Explosive or munitions emergency” means a situation that:
In the professional opinion of an explosive or munitions emergency response specialist, creates an actual or imminent threat to:
Human health, including safety; or
The environment, including property; and
May require immediate and expeditious action by an explosives or munitions specialist to control, mitigate, or eliminate the threat involving the suspected or detected presence of:
Unexploded ordnance (UXO);
Damaged explosives or munitions;
Deteriorated explosives or munitions;
An improvised explosive device (IED);
Some other material or device that is potentially explosive; or
Some other potentially harmful military chemical munition or device.

“Explosives or munitions emergency response” means all immediate response activities by an explosives and munitions emergency response specialist to control, mitigate, or eliminate the actual or potential threat encountered during an explosives or munitions emergency, including:
For example, the following activities:
In-place render-safe procedures;
Treatment or destruction of explosives or munitions; or
Transporting explosives or munitions to another location to be rendered safe, treated, or destroyed;
Activities undertaken to deal with an explosives or munitions emergency after a reasonable delay caused by a necessary, unforeseen, or uncontrollable circumstance; and
Activities undertaken to deal with an explosives or munitions emergency on public lands, on private lands, at RCRA facilities, and at locations that are not RCRA facilities.

“Explosives or munitions emergency response specialist” means an individual trained in chemical or conventional munitions or explosives handling, transportation, render-safe procedures, or destruction techniques, including:
Department of Defense (DOD) emergency explosive ordnance disposal (EOD) personnel;
DOD technical escort unit (TEU) personnel;
DOD-certified civilian or contractor personnel; and
Other federal, State, or local government or civilian personnel trained in explosives or munitions emergency responses similar to the individuals identified in §B(22-4)(a)(c) of this regulation.

“Facility” means all continuous land, and structures, other appurtenances, and improvements on the land, used for treating, storing, or disposing of hazardous waste. A facility may consist of several treatment, storage, or disposal operational units (for example, one or more landfills, surface impoundments, or combinations of them).
“Facility mailing list” means the mailing list developed by the Department in accordance with COMAR 26.13.07.20-2E(1)(d).

“Federal agency” means any department, agency, or other instrumentality of the federal government, any independent agency or establishment of the federal government, including any government corporation, and the Government Printing Office.
“FFDCA” means the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, 21 U.S.C. §§321-394.
“FIFRA” means the Federal Insecticide, Fungicide and Rodenticide Act, 7 U.S.C. §136-136y.

“Final closure” means the closure of all hazardous waste management units at the facility in accordance with all applicable closure requirements so that hazardous waste management activities under COMAR 26.13.05 and 26.13.06 are no longer conducted at the facility unless subject to the provisions in COMAR 26.13.03.03-3—.03-10 and COMAR 26.13.03.05-1—.05-2.
“Food-chain crops” means tobacco, crops grown for human consumption and crops grown for feed for animals whose products are consumed by humans.
“Freeboard” means the vertical distance between the top of a tank or surface impoundment dike, and the surface of the waste contained in it.
“Free liquids” means liquids which readily separate from the solid portion of a waste under ambient temperature and pressure.
“Fully regulated generator” means a person who generates hazardous waste and does not meet the definition of a Maryland-defined small quantity generator;

“Generator” means any person, by site, whose act or process produces hazardous waste identified or listed in COMAR 26.13.02 or whose act first causes a hazardous waste to become subject to regulation.
“Ground water” means water below the land surface in a zone of saturation.
“Hazardous debris” means debris that contains a hazardous waste listed in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19 or that exhibits a characteristic of hazardous waste identified in COMAR 26.13.02.10—.14.

Agency Note: Any deliberate mixing of hazardous waste prohibited from land disposal under 40 CFR Part 268 Subpart C with debris that changes its treatment classification, that is, from “waste” to “hazardous debris”, is not allowed under the dilution prohibition of 40 CFR §268.3.
“Hazardous secondary material” means a secondary material, such as a spent material, by-product, or sludge, that, if discarded, would be identified as a hazardous waste under COMAR 26.13.02.
“Hazardous waste” means a hazardous waste as defined in COMAR 26.13.02. Hazardous waste shall be synonymous with Controlled Hazardous Substance or CHS, except as provided in COMAR 26.13.02.06.

“Hazardous waste discharge” means the accidental or intentional spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, or dumping of hazardous waste or a material listed in COMAR 26.13.02.19 which, because it is discharged, becomes a hazardous waste, onto or into the land or water.
“Hazardous waste incinerator” means an enclosed device used to thermally treat or decompose a hazard waste that:
Uses controlled flame combustion, does not meet the criteria for classification as a boiler, sludge dryer, or carbon regeneration unit, and is not listed as an industrial furnace; or
Meets the definition of infrared incinerator or plasma arc incinerator.

“Hazardous waste management unit” is a contiguous area of land on or in which hazardous waste is placed, or the largest area in which there is significant likelihood of mixing hazardous waste constituents in the same area. Examples of hazardous waste management units include a surface impoundment, a waste pile, a land treatment area, a landfill cell, an incinerator, a tank and its associated piping and underlying containment system, and a container storage area. A container alone does not constitute a unit. The unit includes containers and the land or pad upon which they are placed.
Hazardous Waste Pharmaceutical.
“Hazardous waste pharmaceutical” means a pharmaceutical that is a solid waste as defined in COMAR 26.13.02.02 and:
Exhibits one or more characteristics identified in COMAR 26.13.02.10—.14; or
Is listed in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19.
“Hazardous waste pharmaceutical” does not include:
A pharmaceutical that will be legitimately used or reused by, for example, being lawfully donated for use for its intended purpose;
A pharmaceutical that is reclaimed, as described in COMAR 26.13.02.01D(7);

An over-the-counter pharmaceutical, dietary supplement, or homeopathic drug for which there is a reasonable expectation that the item will be legitimately used or reused by, for example, being lawfully redistributed for use for its intended purpose; or
An over-the-counter pharmaceutical, dietary supplement, or homeopathic drug for which there is a reasonable expectation that the item will be reclaimed.
Healthcare Facility.
“Healthcare facility” means any person that is legally authorized to:
