section.heading: Purpose and Scope.
section.text: This chapter:

para.text: Identifies certain requirements associated with the management of hazardous wastes that are to be land disposed;
Applies to:
Generators of hazardous waste;
Transporters of hazardous waste;
Owners and operators of hazardous waste facilities; and
Reverse distributors; and
Does not apply to a hazardous waste that is listed in COMAR 26.13.02.16—.19 but is not listed in 40 CFR §§261.30—261.34, unless the waste:
Exhibits a characteristic of hazardous waste; or
Is otherwise subject to the requirements identified in Regulation .03 of this chapter.

annotation.cite: Environment Article, Title 7, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland

annotations.annotation: Effective date: January 13, 2022 (49:1 Md. R. 14)
Regulation .01 amended effective October 1, 2025 (52:17 Md. R. 876)

section.heading: Recyclable Materials Used in a Manner Constituting Disposal.

para.text: Applicability.
This regulation applies to recyclable materials that are applied to or placed on the land:
Without mixing with any other substance or substances; or
After mixing or combining with any other substance or substances.
The materials in §A(1) of this regulation are referred to throughout this regulation as “materials used in a manner that constitutes disposal”.

Except as provided in §A(4) and (5) of this regulation, products produced for the general public's use that are used in a manner that constitutes disposal and that contain recyclable materials are not presently subject to regulation if:
The recyclable materials have undergone a chemical reaction in the course of producing the product so as to become inseparable by physical means;
For each recyclable material, that is, hazardous waste, that the product contains, the product meets the applicable:
Treatment standards in 40 CFR Part 268, Subpart D; or
Prohibition levels in 40 CFR §268.32 or RCRA §3004(d), if no treatment standards have been established under 40 CFR Part 268, Subpart D; and
The recycler complies with the requirements of 40 CFR §268.7(b)(6), either directly or, if located in Maryland, as qualified by COMAR 26.13.09.03B.

Slags that are generated from high temperature metals recovery (HTMR) processing of hazardous waste K061, K062, and F006, and that are used as an antiskid agent or deicing agent in a manner that constitutes disposal, are not covered by the exemption in §A(3) of this regulation.

A fertilizer that contains recyclable materials is not subject to regulation as hazardous waste when used for its intended purpose if the fertilizer meets the applicable treatment standard in 40 CFR Part 268, Subpart D, for each recyclable material, that is, hazardous waste, that it contains.

Standards Applicable to Generators and Transporters of Materials Used in a Manner That Constitutes Disposal. Generators and transporters of materials that are used in a manner that constitutes disposal are subject to the applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.03 and 26.13.04 and the notification requirement of Section 3010 of RCRA.

Standards Applicable to Storers of Materials That Are To Be Used in a Manner That Constitutes Disposal, Who Are Not the Ultimate Users. Owners or operators of facilities that store recyclable materials that are to be used in a manner that constitutes disposal, but who are not the ultimate users of the materials, are regulated under all applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.02, 26.13.05.01—.12, 26.13.06.01—.20, and 26.13.07, and the notification requirement under §3010 of RCRA.
Standards Applicable to Users of Materials That Are Used in a Manner That Constitutes Disposal.

Owners or operators of facilities that use recyclable materials in a manner that constitutes disposal are regulated under all applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.02, 26.13.05, 26.13.06, 26.13.07, and 26.13.09 and §3010 of RCRA, except that these requirements do not apply to products which contain these recyclable materials under the provisions of §A(3) of this regulation.
The use of waste or used oil or other material, which is contaminated with a hazardous waste, for dust suppression or road treatment is prohibited.
Applicability.
Except as provided in §B of this regulation, this regulation applies to spent lead-acid batteries that are recyclable materials.
For the purposes of this regulation, “spent batteries” means spent lead-acid batteries that are recyclable materials.
A person may choose to manage spent lead-acid batteries under the provisions applicable to universal waste batteries in COMAR 26.13.10.06—.25, rather than under the requirements of this regulation.
Management Requirements — General.
Persons who manage spent batteries as described in §C(2) of this regulation shall comply with the applicable regulatory requirements in the sections that are cross-referenced.
Persons who manage spent batteries that are to be reclaimed:
By regeneration, shall comply with §D of this regulation; and
By a means other than regeneration and who:
Store the spent batteries at a permitted CHS facility before reclaiming them, shall comply with §E of this regulation;
Store the spent batteries at an interim status facility before reclaiming them, shall comply with §F of this regulation;
Do not store the spent batteries before they reclaim them, shall comply with §G of this regulation;
Store the spent batteries before they are reclaimed by others, shall comply with §H of this regulation; and
Generate, collect, or transport the spent batteries, shall comply with §I of this regulation.
Persons who export batteries to be reclaimed through regeneration or any other means in a foreign country shall comply with §J of this regulation.
Persons who transport batteries to export them to be reclaimed through regeneration or any other means in a foreign country shall comply with §K of this regulation.
Requirements — Reclamation by Regeneration. Persons who manage spent batteries that are to be reclaimed through regeneration, such as by electrolyte replacement:
Are exempt from the following requirements with respect to management of those batteries, including the regeneration:
COMAR 26.13.03, except for COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
The notification requirements of §3010 of RCRA; and
Are subject to the requirements of COMAR 26.13.02.

Requirements — Permitted Facilities That Reclaim Spent Batteries. Owners or operators of facilities that store spent batteries before reclaiming them by a means other than regeneration are subject to the following requirements:
Notification requirements under §3010 of RCRA;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.02;
COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.05.01—.12, except for:
COMAR 26.13.05.02D, which concerns waste analysis;
COMAR 26.13.05.05B, which concerns use of manifests; and
COMAR 26.13.05.05C, which concerns manifest discrepancies;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.07 and .09; and
If the batteries are imported from a foreign country, 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.

Requirements — Interim Status Facilities That Reclaim Spent Batteries. Owners or operators of interim status facilities that store spent batteries before reclaiming them by a means other than regeneration are subject to the following requirements:
Notification requirements under §3010 of RCRA;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.02;
COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.06, except for:
COMAR 26.13.05.02D, which concerns waste analysis, and which the owner or operator would otherwise be required to comply with by COMAR 26.13.06.02A;
COMAR 26.13.05.05B, which concerns use of manifests, and which the owner or operator would otherwise be required to comply with by COMAR 26.13.06.05; and
COMAR 26.13.05.05C, which concerns manifest discrepancies, and which the owner or operator would otherwise be required to comply with by COMAR 26.13.06.05;
All applicable provisions of COMAR 26.13.07 and .09; and
If the batteries are imported from a foreign country, 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.
Requirements — Reclamation Without Storage. Persons who reclaim spent batteries by a method other than regeneration and do not store the spent batteries before reclaiming them are:
Exempt from the following requirements with respect to those batteries:
COMAR 26.13.03, except for COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
The notification requirements of §3010 of RCRA; and
Subject to:
Applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.09; and
If the batteries are imported from a foreign country, 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.

Requirements — Storage Before Reclamation by Persons Other Than the Reclaimer. Persons who store spent batteries that are to be reclaimed by a method other than regeneration, and who do not themselves reclaim the batteries are:
Exempt from the following requirements with respect to those batteries:
COMAR 26.13.03, except for COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
The notification requirements of §3010 of RCRA; and
Subject to:
Applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.09; and
If the batteries are imported from a foreign country, 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.

Requirements — Generation, Collection, and Transport of Batteries That Will Be Reclaimed. Persons who generate, collect, or transport spent batteries that will be reclaimed by a method other than regeneration, or who perform any combination of these activities, are:
Exempt from the following requirements with respect to those batteries:
COMAR 26.13.03, except for COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination;
The notification requirements of §3010 of RCRA; and
Subject to the applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.09.
Requirements — Exports of Batteries That Will Be Reclaimed. Persons who export batteries to be reclaimed through regeneration or any other means in a foreign country are:
Exempt from the following requirements with respect to those batteries:
COMAR 26.13.03, except for COMAR 26.13.03.02, which concerns hazardous waste determination; and
COMAR 26.13.04—.07 and .09; and
Subject to 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.

Requirements — Transport of Batteries That Will Be Exported and Reclaimed. Persons who transport batteries in the U.S. to export them to be reclaimed through regeneration or any other means in a foreign country are:
Exempt from the following requirements with respect to those batteries:
COMAR 26.13.04—.07 and .09; and
The notification requirements of §3010 of RCRA; and
Subject to 40 CFR Part 262, Subpart H.

section.heading: Scope — Standards for Universal Waste Management.
section.text: This regulation and Regulations .07—.25 of this chapter:

para.text: Establish requirements for managing universal waste;
Include standards for managing the following:
Batteries, as described in Regulation .07 of this chapter;
Pesticides, as described in Regulation .08 of this chapter;
Lamps, mercury-containing equipment, or PCB-containing lamp ballasts, each as described in Regulation .09 of this chapter; and
Aerosol cans, as described in Regulation .09-1 of this chapter; and
Provide an alternative set of management standards to COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.09 and Regulations .01—.05 of this chapter.

Except for pesticides identified in §B of this regulation, or as otherwise specified in §B of this regulation, the requirements of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter apply to persons managing pesticides, as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03B, meeting the following conditions:
Recalled pesticides that are stocks of:

A suspended and canceled pesticide that is part of a voluntary or mandatory recall under §19(b) of FIFRA, including, but not limited to, those owned by the registrant responsible for conducting the recall; or
A suspended or canceled pesticide, or a pesticide that is not in compliance with FIFRA, that is part of a voluntary recall by the registrant; and
Stocks of unused pesticide products, other than those identified in §A(1) of this regulation, that are collected and managed as part of a waste pesticide collection program.
Except as otherwise noted in this section, the requirements of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter do not apply to management of the following pesticides:

Recalled pesticides described in §A(1) of this regulation, and unused pesticide products described in §A(2) of this regulation, that are managed by farmers in compliance with COMAR 26.13.03.07-4, which addresses disposal of pesticides by a farmer on the farmer's own farm in a manner consistent with the disposal instructions on the pesticide label;

Except for a pesticide in an aerosol can as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03, pesticides not meeting the conditions of §A of this regulation, which shall instead be managed in compliance with the hazardous waste regulations in COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10.05;
A pesticide in an aerosol can as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03 that does not meet the conditions of §A of this regulation, which shall be managed either:
As aerosol can universal waste in compliance with:
Regulation .16-1 of this chapter or Regulation .20F of this chapter; and
All other applicable requirements of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter; or
In compliance with the hazardous waste regulations in COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10.05
Pesticides that are not wastes under COMAR 26.13.02, including pesticides that:
Do not meet the criteria for waste generation in §C of this regulation; or
Are not wastes as described in §D of this regulation; and
Pesticides that do not meet the definition of hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.03.
Determining When a Pesticide Becomes a Waste.
A recalled pesticide described in §A(1) of this regulation becomes a waste on the first date on which both of the following conditions apply:
The generator of the recalled pesticide agrees to participate in the recall; and
The person conducting the recall decides to discard the pesticide, with “discard” being defined by the criteria in COMAR 26.13.02.02A(2).
An unused pesticide product described in §A(2) of this regulation becomes a waste on the date that the generator decides to discard it.
Pesticides That Are Not Wastes.
Recalled Pesticides.
Recalled pesticides described in §A(1) of this regulation are not wastes, if the person conducting the recall:
Has not made a decision to discard the pesticide, with “discard” being defined by the criteria of COMAR 26.13.02.02A(2); or
Has made a decision to use a management option that, under COMAR 26.13.02.02, 40 CFR §261.2, or an equivalent regulation in another state, does not cause the pesticide to be a solid waste.
Until a decision to discard a pesticide is made in accordance with §D(1)(a)(i) of this regulation, the pesticide:

Is not a solid waste and therefore, is not a hazardous waste subject to hazardous waste requirements, including the standards for universal waste management in Regulations .06—.24 of this chapter; and
Remains subject to the requirements of FIFRA.
If a decision is made to manage a pesticide in a manner that does not cause the pesticide to be a solid waste, in accordance with §D(1)(a)(ii) of this regulation, the pesticide:
Is not a hazardous waste and is not subject to hazardous waste requirements, including the standards for universal waste management in Regulations .06—.24 of this chapter; and
Remains subject to the requirements of FIFRA, even if it is to be exported to a foreign destination for use or reuse.
Unused Pesticide Products.

An unused pesticide product described in §A(2) of this regulation is not a waste if the generator of the unused pesticide product has not decided to discard it, with “discard” being defined by the criteria of COMAR 26.13.02.02A(2).
The unused pesticide products described in §D(2)(a) of this regulation remain subject to the requirements of FIFRA.
Except for aerosol cans identified in §B of this regulation, the requirements of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter apply to persons managing aerosol cans as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03B.
The requirements of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter do not apply to the management of an aerosol can that:
Is not yet waste under COMAR 26.13.02, including an aerosol can that does not meet the criteria for waste generation in §C of this regulation;
Does not meet the criteria of §D of this regulation to be regulated as hazardous waste; or
Qualifies as an empty container under the provisions of COMAR 26.13.02.07B.
Generation of Waste Aerosol Cans.
A used aerosol can becomes a waste on the date the can is discarded, with “discarded” being defined by the criteria of COMAR 26.13.02.02A(2).
An unused aerosol can becomes a waste on the date the handler decides to discard the can.
Criteria to be Regulated as Hazardous Waste. An aerosol can is regulated as hazardous waste if the aerosol can:
Exhibits one or more of the characteristics of hazardous waste identified in COMAR 26.13.02.10—.14;
Contains a substance listed in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19; or
Otherwise meets the definition of hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.03.

Voluntary Management. A person managing an aerosol can excluded under §B of this regulation may voluntarily elect to manage the aerosol can in accordance with the provisions of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter.

section.heading: Small Quantity Handlers of Universal Waste Mercury-Containing Equipment — Specific Management Standards.

para.text: General.

A small quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste mercury-containing equipment in a way that prevents release of any universal waste or any component of universal waste to the environment.

For the purposes of this regulation, “open original housing” means a tube or similar object that is open at one end and that holds mercury while the mercury performs a function in a piece of mercury-containing equipment.
A small quantity handler of universal waste:
Shall place any universal waste mercury-containing equipment identified in §B(2) of this regulation in a container that is:
Kept closed, unless waste is being added to or removed from the container;
Structurally sound;
Compatible with the contents of the mercury-containing equipment;
Free of evidence of leakage, spillage, or damage that could cause leakage under reasonably foreseeable conditions; and
Reasonably designed to prevent the escape of mercury into the environment by volatilization or any other means;
Shall place the following universal waste mercury-containing equipment in a container that satisfies the requirements of §B(1)(a)—(e) of this regulation:
Mercury-containing equipment that shows evidence of leakage, spillage, or damage that could cause leakage under reasonably foreseeable conditions;
Mercury-containing equipment with noncontained elemental mercury, such as equipment that contains mercury in:
An open original housing that has not been sealed in a way that prevents release of mercury to the environment during accumulation or transportation; or

A part of the device into which mercury has escaped from the part of the device designed to hold mercury, such as a valve that separates mercury in the mercury-containing equipment from the rest of the device; and
Ancillary equipment, such as a valve or other component of mercury-containing equipment that has come into contact with mercury and been removed from the mercury-containing equipment;
May remove mercury-containing ampules from universal waste mercury-containing equipment, if the handler:
Removes and manages the ampules in a manner designed to prevent breakage of the ampules;
Removes ampules only over or in a containment device, such as a tray or pan, sufficient to collect and contain any mercury released from an ampule if the ampule were to break;
Ensures that a mercury clean-up system is readily available to immediately transfer any mercury resulting from spills or leaks, as required by §B(3)(d) of this regulation;

Immediately transfers any mercury resulting from spills or leaks from broken ampules from the containment device required by §B(3)(b) of this regulation to a container that meets and is managed in accordance with all applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10;

Ensures that the area in which ampules are removed is well ventilated and monitored to ensure compliance with applicable exposure levels for mercury established by the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the Maryland Occupational Safety and Health (MOSH) program;

Ensures that employees removing ampules are thoroughly familiar with proper waste mercury handling and emergency procedures, including transfer of mercury from containment devices to appropriate containers;
Stores removed ampules in closed, nonleaking containers that are in good condition; and
Ensures that packing materials adequate to prevent breakage during storage, handling, and transportation are used in packing removed ampules in the container required by §B(3)(g) of this regulation;
May remove an open original housing holding mercury from universal waste mercury-containing equipment if the handler:
Immediately seals the original housing holding the mercury with an air-tight seal to prevent any release of mercury to the environment; and

In handling the open original housing and the original housing after it has been sealed, manages the housing in accordance with the requirements of §B(3) of this regulation that apply to mercury-containing ampules;
May remove from mercury-containing equipment any ancillary equipment that has come in contact with mercury and may manage it as universal waste mercury-containing equipment if the handler:
Removes and manages the ancillary equipment in a manner designed to prevent releases of mercury;
Removes the ancillary equipment only over or in a containment device, such as a tray or pan, sufficient to collect and contain any mercury that may be released from the ancillary equipment; and
Manages the ancillary equipment during and after its removal in accordance with the requirements of §B(3)(c)—(h) of this regulation that apply to intact or broken mercury-containing ampules; and

Shall comply with the following requirements if the handler removes mercury-containing ampules or ancillary equipment from mercury-containing equipment, or if the handler seals mercury from mercury-containing equipment in its original housing:
Determine whether the following meet the definition of hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.03:
Mercury or clean-up residues resulting from spills or leaks; and
Other solid waste generated as a result of the removal of mercury-containing ampules, housings, or ancillary equipment, such as the remaining mercury-containing device;
If a waste identified in §B(6)(a) of this regulation meets the definition of hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.03, the handler:
Shall manage the waste in compliance with all applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10; and
Is considered to be the generator of the waste and shall manage it in accordance with the requirements of COMAR 26.13.03; and

If a waste identified in §B(6)(a) of this regulation does not meet the definition of hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.03, the handler shall manage the waste in compliance with applicable federal, State, or local solid waste regulations.

section.heading: Small Quantity Handlers of Universal Waste Aerosol Cans — Specific Management Standards.

para.text: A small quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste aerosol cans in a way that prevents any releases of universal waste or a component of universal waste to the environment.
A small quantity handler of universal waste shall:
Accumulate universal waste aerosol cans in a container that is:
Structurally sound;
Compatible with the contents of the aerosol cans;
Lacking evidence of:
Leakage;
Spillage; or
Damage that could cause leakage under reasonably foreseeable conditions; and
Protected from sources of heat;
Manage a universal waste aerosol can that show evidence of leakage by:
Packaging the aerosol can in a separate closed container;
Overpacking the aerosol can in a container with absorbents; or
Immediately puncturing and draining the aerosol can in accordance with the requirements of §D of this regulation.
A small quantity handler of universal waste may conduct the following activities if each individual aerosol can is not breached and remains intact:
Sorting aerosol cans by type;
Commingling intact aerosol cans in one container; and
Removing actuators to reduce the risk that an accidental release will occur.
A small quantity handler of universal waste aerosol cans who punctures and drains a universal waste aerosol can shall:
Recycle the empty punctured aerosol can;
Conduct puncturing and draining activities using a device specifically designed to:
Safely puncture aerosol cans; and
Effectively contain the residual contents from the punctured can and any related emissions;
Establish and follow a written procedure that specifies how to safely puncture and drain the universal waste aerosol can, including details about the following topics:
Proper assembly, operation, and maintenance of the device used for the activity;
Segregation of incompatible wastes generated; and
Proper waste management practices to prevent fires and releases;
Maintain, on site, a copy of the manufacturer’s operating instructions and specifications for the device that is being used for puncturing and draining;
Ensure that persons performing puncturing and draining activities are trained in the proper procedures for conducting the activities.
Ensure that puncturing of the can is done in a manner that:
Is designed to prevent fires and prevent the release of any component of universal waste to the environment; and
In addition to other appropriate measures to satisfy the requirements of §D(6(a) of this regulation, includes locating the puncturing equipment on a solid, flat surface in a well-ventilated area;
Immediately transfer the contents from the waste aerosol can or puncturing device, if applicable, to a container or tank that meets the applicable requirements in:
Conduct a hazardous waste determination in accordance with the requirements of COMAR 26.13.03.02—.02-2 on:
The contents emptied from the aerosol can;
The punctured, drained aerosol can if the aerosol can does not meet the criteria of COMAR 26.13.02.07B to be considered “empty”; and
Any other solid waste generated in connection with the puncturing and draining of the aerosol can;

Manage any hazardous waste generated as a result of puncturing and draining the aerosol can in accordance with all applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.01—.10, with the universal waste handler being considered the generator of the hazardous waste and subject to the requirements of COMAR 26.13.03;
Manage nonhazardous waste generated as a result of puncturing and draining the aerosol can in accordance with applicable State, federal, and local solid waste regulations; and
Satisfy the following requirements concerning emergency preparedness and response:
Have in place a written procedure on how to respond in the event of a spill or leak to minimize risks to human health and the environment;
Have a spill cleanup kit readily available; and
Promptly clean up any spill or leak of the contents of an aerosol can.

section.heading: Small Quantity Handlers of Universal Waste — General Management Standards.

para.text: Labeling and Marking.
A small quantity handler of universal waste shall label or mark the universal waste to identify the type of universal waste as specified in §A(2) of this regulation.
A small quantity handler of universal waste shall:
Clearly label or mark each universal waste battery that is not in a container, and each container in which universal waste batteries are being held with one of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—Battery(ies)”;
“Waste Battery(ies)”; or
“Used Battery(ies)”;

Ensure that each container, multiple-container package unit, tank, transport vehicle or vessel which contains recalled universal waste pesticides, as described in Regulation .08A(1) of this chapter, is clearly labeled or marked with:
The label that was on or accompanied the product as sold or distributed; and
The words “Universal Waste—Pesticide(s)” or “Waste—Pesticide(s)”;
Ensure that each container, tank, transport vehicle, or vessel containing unused pesticide products as described in Regulation .08A(2) of this chapter is clearly labeled or marked with:
The label that was on the product when purchased, if the label is still legible;
The appropriate label as required under the U.S. Department of Transportation regulation, 49 CFR 172, if using the label described by §A(2)(c)(i) of this regulation is not feasible;

Another label prescribed or designated by the waste pesticide collection program administered or recognized by the State, if using the label described by §A(2)(c)(i) or (ii) of this regulation is not feasible; and
The words “Universal Waste—Pesticide(s)” or “Waste—Pesticide(s)”;

Except as provided in §A(3) of this regulation, clearly label or mark each item of universal waste mercury-containing equipment that is not in a container, and each container in which universal waste mercury-containing equipment is being held, with one of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—Mercury-Containing Equipment”;
“Waste Mercury—Containing Equipment”; or
“Used Mercury—Containing Equipment”;
Clearly label or mark each universal waste lamp that is not in a container, and each container or package in which universal waste lamps are being held, with one of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—Lamp(s)”;
“Waste Lamp(s)”; or
“Used Lamp(s)”; and

Clearly label or mark each universal waste PCB-containing lamp ballast that is not in a container, and each container or package in which universal waste PCB-containing lamp ballasts are being held, with one of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—PCB-containing lamp ballast(s)”;
“Waste PCB-containing lamp ballast(s)”; or
“Used PCB-containing lamp ballast(s)”.
Clearly label or mark each universal waste aerosol can that is not in a container, and each container in which universal waste aerosol cans are being held with one of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—Aerosol Can(s)”;
“Waste Aerosol Can(s)”; or
“Used Aerosol Can(s)

As an alternative to the requirements of §A(2)(d) of this regulation, a small quantity handler of universal waste mercury-containing equipment may clearly label or mark a universal waste mercury-containing thermostat or a container that holds only universal waste mercury-containing thermostats with any of the following phrases:
“Universal Waste—Mercury Thermostats”;
“Waste Mercury Thermostat(s) “; or
“Used Mercury Thermostat(s)”.
Accumulation Time Limits.

Unless the requirements of §B(2) of this regulation are met, a small quantity handler of universal waste may accumulate universal waste for not longer than 1 year from the date the universal waste is generated, or received from another universal waste handler.
A small quantity handler of universal waste may accumulate universal waste for longer than 1 year from the date the universal waste is generated, or received from another universal waste handler, if:

Accumulation of the universal waste for a period longer than 1 year is solely for the purpose of accumulation of a quantity of universal waste as necessary to facilitate proper recovery, treatment, or disposal; and

The handler can demonstrate, on request of the Department, and to the satisfaction of the Secretary, that accumulation of the universal waste for more than 1 year is solely for the purpose of accumulation of a quantity of universal waste as necessary to facilitate proper recovery, treatment, or disposal.
A small quantity handler of universal waste shall:
Be able to demonstrate the length of time that the universal waste has been accumulated from the date it becomes a waste or is received; and
Make the demonstration required by §B(3)(a) of this regulation by:
Placing the universal waste in a container and marking or labeling the container with the earliest date that any universal waste in the container became a waste or was received by the handler;
Marking or labeling each individual item of universal waste, such as each battery or thermostat, with the date the individual item became a waste or was received by the handler;
Maintaining an inventory system on-site that identifies the date each universal waste became a waste or was received by the handler;

Maintaining an inventory system on-site that identifies the earliest date that any universal waste in a group of universal waste items or a group of containers of universal waste became a waste or was received by the handler;
Placing the universal waste in a specific accumulation area and identifying the earliest date that any universal waste in the area became a waste or was received by the handler; or
Using any other method that clearly demonstrates the length of time that the universal waste has been accumulated from the date it becomes a waste or is received by the handler.
Employee Training. A small quantity handler of universal waste shall provide the following information to all employees who handle or have responsibility for managing universal waste:
Proper handling procedures for each type of universal waste handled at the facility; and
Emergency procedures appropriate for the types of universal waste handled at the facility.
Response to Release.
A small quantity handler of universal waste shall:
Immediately contain all releases of universal wastes and other residues from universal wastes; and

Determine whether any material resulting from a release associated with the management of universal waste is hazardous waste, and if it is, manage the hazardous waste in compliance with all applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10.
If a small quantity handler of universal waste has a release of hazardous waste, the handler:
Is considered the generator of the hazardous waste resulting from the release; and
Shall manage the hazardous waste in compliance with COMAR 26.13.03.

section.heading: Large Quantity Handlers of Universal Waste — General Requirements.

para.text: Applicability.
This regulation and Regulations .20 and .21 of this chapter apply to large quantity handlers of universal waste as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03B.

A universal waste handler retains the classification of a large quantity handler of universal waste at least until the end of the calendar year in which the handler was classified as a large quantity handler, even if the amount of universal waste that the handler has accumulated becomes less than 5,000 kilograms.

If a handler does not have an accumulation of 5,000 kilograms or more of universal waste on January 1 of a given year, the handler may elect to be regulated as a small quantity handler of universal waste under Regulations .11—.18 of this chapter until the handler accumulates 5,000 kilograms or more of universal waste for the first time in that calendar year.
Prohibitions. A large quantity handler of universal waste may not:
Dispose of universal waste, unless the handler does so under authority of a hazardous waste disposal facility permit; or
Dilute or treat universal waste, except:
In responding to releases as provided in Regulation .21D of this chapter;
As provided in Regulation .20 of this chapter; or
In accordance with a hazardous waste treatment facility permit.
Notification.
Except as provided in §C(2) of this regulation, a large quantity handler of universal waste, before accumulating 5,000 kilograms of universal waste for the first time, shall:
Send to the Secretary a written notification that includes the following information:
The universal waste handler's name and mailing address;
The name and business telephone number of the person at the universal waste handler's site who should be contacted regarding universal waste management activities;
The address or location of the universal waste management activities;
A list of all the types of universal waste managed by the handler, such as “batteries, pesticides, mercury-containing equipment, aerosol cans, and lamps”; and
A statement indicating that the handler is accumulating more than 5,000 kilograms of universal waste at one time; and
Obtain an EPA identification number from the Department.

A large quantity handler of universal waste who has already notified EPA or the Department of the handler's hazardous waste management activities and who has received an EPA identification number is considered to have satisfied the requirements of §C(1) of this regulation.

section.heading: Large Quantity Handlers of Universal Waste — Specific Management Standards.

para.text: Universal Waste Batteries. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste batteries in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .12 of this chapter.

Universal Waste Pesticides. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste pesticides in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .13 of this chapter.

Universal Waste Mercury-Containing Equipment. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste mercury-containing equipment in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .14 of this chapter.

Universal Waste Lamps. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste lamps in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .15 of this chapter.

Universal Waste PCB-Containing Lamp Ballasts. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste PCB-containing lamp ballasts in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .16 of this chapter.

Universal Waste Aerosol Cans. A large quantity handler of universal waste shall manage universal waste aerosol cans in accordance with the requirements established for small quantity handlers in Regulation .16-1 of this chapter.

section.heading: Petitions to Include Other Wastes as Universal Wastes.

para.text: General Requirements.

Except as provided in §C of this regulation, a person seeking to add a hazardous waste or a category of hazardous waste to the universal waste regulations of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter may petition for a regulatory amendment under this regulation and COMAR 26.13.01.04A and J.
General requirements relating to these petitions are established in COMAR 26.13.01.04J.

Evaluative Factors for Petitions to Include Other Wastes as Universal Wastes. In considering whether to grant or deny a petition to add a hazardous waste or a category of hazardous waste to the universal waste regulations of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter, the Secretary shall consider:
The extent to which:
The waste or category of waste, as generated by a large variety of generators, is listed as a hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.15—.19;

A proportion of the waste stream as generated by a large variety of generators, if not listed as a hazardous waste in COMAR 26.13.02.15.19, exhibits one or more of the characteristics of hazardous waste identified in COMAR 26.13.02.10.14;
The waste or category of waste is:
Not exclusive to a specific industry or group of industries; and

Commonly generated by a wide variety of types of establishments, including, for example, households, retail and commercial businesses, office complexes, Maryland-defined small quantity generators, small businesses, government organizations, and large industrial facilities;
The waste or category of waste is:
Generated by a large number of generators; and
Frequently generated in relatively small quantities by each generator;
Systems to be used for collecting the waste or category of waste, including packaging, marking, and labeling practices, would ensure close stewardship of the waste;
The risk posed by the waste or category of waste during accumulation and transport is relatively low compared to other hazardous wastes;

Specific management standards proposed or referenced by the petitioner, such as waste management requirements appropriate to be added to Regulations .12—.16 of this chapter, Regulation .20 of this chapter, Regulation .22C of this chapter, or applicable U.S. Department of Transportation requirements, would be protective of human health and the environment during accumulation and transport;

Regulation of the waste or category of waste under Regulations .06—.24 of this chapter will increase the likelihood that the waste will be diverted from nonhazardous waste management systems, such as the municipal waste stream, nonhazardous industrial or commercial waste stream, municipal sewer or stormwater systems, to recycling, treatment, or disposal in compliance with Subtitle C of RCRA; and
Regulation of the waste or category of waste under Regulations .06—.24 of this chapter will improve implementation of and compliance with the hazardous waste regulatory program; and
Any factors in addition to those identified in §B(1) of this regulation that may be appropriate.

Hazardous waste pharmaceuticals are regulated by Regulations .32—.49 of this chapter and may not be added to the universal waste regulations of Regulations .06—.25 of this chapter as a category of universal waste.
Scope. This regulation and Regulations .33—.49 of this chapter:
Establish requirements for the management of hazardous waste pharmaceuticals by healthcare facilities and reverse distributors; and
Identify certain pharmaceuticals that are excluded from regulation under COMAR 26.13.01—.10.
Defined Terms. The following terms used in this regulation and Regulations .33—.49 of this chapter have the meaning stated in COMAR 26.13.01.03B:
“Evaluated hazardous waste pharmaceutical”;
“Hazardous waste pharmaceutical”;
“Healthcare facility”;
“Household waste pharmaceutical”;
“Long-term care facility”;
“Non-creditable hazardous waste pharmaceutical”;
“Non-hazardous waste pharmaceutical”;
“Non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste”;
“Pharmaceutical”;
“Potentially creditable hazardous waste pharmaceutical”; and
“Reverse distributor”.
Excluded Materials and Wastes.
Except as specified in this section, the following pharmaceuticals are not subject to regulation under COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10:
A pharmaceutical that is not a solid waste, as defined in COMAR 26.13.02.02, because the pharmaceutical is to be:
Reclaimed; or
Legitimately used or legitimately reused, such as by being lawfully donated for use for the pharmaceutical’s intended purpose;
An over-the-counter pharmaceutical, a dietary supplement, or a homeopathic drug that is not a solid waste, as defined in COMAR 26.13.02.02, because:
The material is going to be reclaimed; or
There is a reasonable expectation that the material will be legitimately used or legitimately reused, such as by being lawfully redistributed for use for its intended purpose;

A pharmaceutical that is being managed in accordance with a recall strategy that has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in accordance with 21 CFR Part 7, Subpart C, except that this regulation and Regulations .33—.49 of this chapter apply to the management of the recalled hazardous waste pharmaceutical after the FDA approves the destruction of the recalled pharmaceutical;

A pharmaceutical that is being managed in accordance with a recall corrective action plan that has been accepted by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) in accordance with 16 CFR Part 1115, except that this regulation and Regulations .33—.49 of this chapter apply to the management of the recalled hazardous waste pharmaceutical after the CPSC approves the destruction of the recalled pharmaceutical;
A pharmaceutical that is being stored during an investigation, during a judicial proceeding, or according to a preservation order until either:
The investigation, judicial proceeding, or preservation order has concluded, and a decision is made to discard the pharmaceutical; or
A decision is made to discard the pharmaceutical before the investigation, judicial proceeding, or preservation order has concluded;

An investigational new drug for which an investigational new drug application is in effect in accordance with the FDA’s regulations in 21 CFR Part 312, except that this regulation and Regulations .33—.49 of this chapter apply to the management of the drug if:
The drug, if discarded, would meet the definition of hazardous waste; and
A decision has been made to discard the investigational new drug, or the FDA has approved the destruction of the investigational new drug; and

A household waste pharmaceutical, including a household waste pharmaceutical that has been collected by an authorized collector as defined by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration if the authorized collector complies with the conditional exemption in Regulations .34A(2) and B of this chapter.

The residue of a hazardous waste pharmaceutical that remains in a stock container, dispensing container, unit dose container, syringe, or intravenous bag that is empty according to the criteria in Regulation .35 of this chapter is not regulated as hazardous waste.
Excluded Facilities.

A healthcare facility that is a very small quantity generator under federal regulations, as described in COMAR 26.13.03.01-1B, when counting all of the hazardous waste it generates in a calendar month, including both hazardous waste pharmaceuticals and non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste:
Is subject to:
Regulation .33 of this chapter, which prohibits the discharge of hazardous waste pharmaceuticals to sewer systems that discharge to publicly owned treatment works; and
Regulation .35 of this chapter, which concerns residues of hazardous waste pharmaceuticals in empty containers;

Has the option of complying with the requirements of §E(3) of this regulation for the management of the facility’s hazardous waste pharmaceuticals, as an alternative to managing the hazardous waste pharmaceuticals in accordance with COMAR 26.13.02.05 and the optional provisions of Regulation .36 of this chapter;
Unless the facility voluntarily elects to manage hazardous waste pharmaceuticals in accordance with the regulations specified in §E(3) of this regulation:
Shall manage the hazardous waste pharmaceuticals it generates in accordance with COMAR 26.13.02.05;
May comply with the optional provisions of Regulation .36 of this chapter; and
Is not subject to the requirements of §E(3) of this regulation; and
Shall manage the non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste it generates in accordance with:

COMAR 26.13.03 if the amount of non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste accumulated by the facility prevents the facility from being classified as a Maryland-defined small quantity generator, as specified in COMAR 26.13.03.01A-3(1); or
COMAR 26.13.02.05 if the amount of non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste accumulated by the facility allows the facility to be classified as a Maryland-defined small quantity generator.
A long-term care facility with 20 beds or fewer:

Is presumed to be a very small quantity generator under federal regulations with respect to all of the hazardous waste it generates in a calendar month, including both hazardous waste pharmaceuticals and non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste, unless the Department is able to demonstrate otherwise; and

Shall comply with §D(1) of this regulation unless the Department demonstrates that the facility does not qualify as a very small quantity generator under federal regulations, taking into account both hazardous waste pharmaceuticals and non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste, in which case the facility shall comply with the requirements of §§E(3) and E(4) of this regulation.
Applicability — Healthcare Facilities and Management of Hazardous Waste Pharmaceuticals.
Based on the criteria specified in COMAR 26.13.03.01-1B, a healthcare facility is subject to the requirements specified in §E(3) of this regulation if, in a calendar month:
The facility:

Meets the criteria to be classified as a federally-defined large quantity generator or a federally-defined small quantity generator based on the amount of non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste generated in a calendar month; and
Generates any quantity of hazardous waste pharmaceuticals;
The facility:
Meets the criteria to be classified as a very small quantity generator under federal regulations, counting only the non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste generated by the facility; and

Generates a quantity of hazardous waste pharmaceuticals that exceeds the criteria to be classified as a very small quantity generator under federal regulations, taking into account only the hazardous waste pharmaceuticals generated by the facility; or

The total amount of hazardous waste that the facility generates, including both hazardous waste pharmaceuticals and non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste, exceeds the criteria to be classified as a very small quantity generator under federal regulations.
§F of this regulation provides a summary, in a tabular format, of the criteria specified in §E(1) of this regulation.
A healthcare facility identified in §E(1) of this regulation is subject to the following instead of COMAR 26.13.02—26.13.06 in managing hazardous waste pharmaceuticals:
Regulations .33—.35, .37—.45, and .47 of this chapter with respect to the management of:
Non-creditable hazardous waste pharmaceuticals; and
Potentially creditable hazardous waste pharmaceuticals if they are not destined for a reverse distributor; and

Regulations .33—.35, .37, .38, .46, and .48 of this chapter with respect to the management of potentially creditable hazardous waste pharmaceuticals that are prescription pharmaceuticals and are destined for a reverse distributor.

A healthcare facility shall manage its non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste in accordance with all applicable requirements of COMAR 26.13.01—26.13.10 based on whether the facility is a fully regulated generator or a Maryland-defined small quantity generator, as defined in COMAR 26.13.01.03B, taking into account the total amount of hazardous waste generated and accumulated, including both pharmaceutical hazardous waste and non-pharmaceutical hazardous waste.
Summary Table — Applicability to Healthcare Facilities.
Table 1 of §F(3) of this regulation:

Summarizes, for most generators, the criteria on the amount of hazardous waste generated in a calendar month that determine whether a healthcare facility is subject to the requirements specified in §E(3) of this regulation; and
Identifies the federal hazardous waste generator category that applies to the facility.

If a healthcare facility also generates any residue or contaminated soil, water, or other debris resulting from the cleanup of a spill, into or on any land or water, of any acute hazardous waste listed in COMAR 26.13.02.16 or COMAR 26.13.02.19E, the facility shall also consider that waste in determining the facility’s federal generator category for the purposes of §E(1) of this regulation, based on the criteria in COMAR 26.13.03.01-1B.
Table 1.
